arm_group.description: Group 1 physicians randomized to the intervention will have access to the Champlain BASE eConsult service in Years One and Two

Group 2 physicians randomized to the control group will conduct their consultation processes as normal during Year One, and will then be granted access to the Champlain BASE eConsult service in Year Two

brief_summary.textblock:
The consultation-referral process is complex, involving several steps including 1) the PCP
      recognizing the need for specialist advice/intervention, 2) patient agreement on seeing the
      specialist, 3) referral letter and information sent to specialist, 4) appointment booked and
      communicated, 5) patient visit(s) with the specialist and 6) communication back to the PCP.

      There are many factors during this process which limit the effectiveness and efficiency of
      patient care.  These include inequitable access for patients and providers, long wait times
      before specialist advice received/implemented, delayed communication and mismatched consult
      expectations. These gaps result in significant breakdowns in transitions of care,
      inappropriate treatment, patient dissatisfaction and potential harm. Moreover, not all
      individuals are willing or able to travel to see specialists in a large academic medical
      centre even when recommended by the PCP.

      eConsultation has the potential for improving transitions in care through improved
      communication ensuring that patients are seen by the right specialist, when necessary, with
      the right information and in a timely manner. The goal of this project is to evaluate the
      impact of eConsultation on specialist referral rates.

clinical_study.brief_title: Building Capacity for Specialized Services Through eConsultation

detailed_description.textblock:
Research Question: What is the impact of, and the patients' perceptions of, an electronic
      consultation service (eConsult) between primary care professionals and specialists?

      The goal of this project is to evaluate a novel electronic referral-consultation process
      between primary care providers and specialists utilizing e-consultation which will:

        1. provide  patient-specific advice to primary care providers (PCPs) in place of a formal
           consultation

        2. provide patient-specific advice to PCPs for further investigations or treatment options
           prior to the formal consultation, resulting in fewer visits required with the
           specialist

        3. provide opportunity for PCPs to receive patient-specific advice on patients previously
           seen by a specialist but no longer followed in the specialty clinic, resulting in
           enhanced confidence of transition of care back to primary care providers thus promoting
           best practices and continuity of care

      Intervention: Building on a recent successful pilot project, and using a pre-existing secure
      web-based collaboration space, primary care providers will submit a patient-specific
      clinical question to a specialist using a standardized electronic form that permits
      attachments (e.g., laboratory results, digital images). The specialist responds within one
      week by either: i) directly answering the question (negating the need for referral), ii)
      asking for additional patient information, or iii) requesting an in-person referral. Results
      from the pilot study (n=18 primary care providers) demonstrated a high level of provider
      satisfaction and resulted in the avoidance of 43% of referrals.

      Design: A mixed methods evaluation approach will be used to meet the objectives of this
      study.

      Quantitative: This will be a clustered randomized controlled trial using a stepped wedge
      design, a type of crossover study in which different groups (in this case, primary care
      providers) cross over from the control arm to the intervention arm at different time points.
      100 providers from across the province of Ontario will be recruited and allocated to either
      Group 1 (50 providers) or Group 2 (50 providers). Please note that in this study, the
      investigators are recruiting primary care providers only. Group 1 providers will have access
      to specialties already available through eConsult in the first year of intervention, while
      Group 2 will use standard referral practices during this time period and will begin using
      eConsult in the second year of intervention. This offset in start times allows the
      investigators to control for temporal effects, as Group 2 will serve as a control for Group
      1. This stepped wedge approach helps overcome several pragmatic issues and avoids ethical
      concerns as all providers will eventually be offered access to the eConsult service.

      Referral data will be collected from the Insitute for Clinical Evaluative Sciences
      (Ontario), the Ontario Health Insurance Plan and IPDB databases for all 100 providers . The
      change in referral rates from the baseline to the end of the study  for both Groups will be
      analyzed, while controlling for temporal effects.

      Sample size: With 50 providers per arm, the investigators will be able to detect a change of
      0.06 referrals/patient/year (referral rate for 12 specialties (# of available specialties
      increases monthly): 0.31 referrals/patient/year) with 80% power using a two-sided test at a
      5% level of significance and using a coefficient of variation of 0.38 to account for
      clustering.

      In year two or three, the investigators will recruit randomly selected patients whose cases
      involved the eConsult system, to gain insight into their views on the acceptability of
      electronic consultations.

      Quantitative Analysis: A clustered, multi-level Poisson regression analysis will be
      conducted using the stepped wedge analysis approach outlined by Hussey and Hughes to examine
      the impact of the eConsult system on referral rates while accounting for practice (model,
      urban/rural), provider (age, sex, years since graduation, baseline referral rate, foreign
      trained) and patient-level (age, sex, socioeconomic status, health status, baseline referral
      rate) characteristics.

      Qualitative Analysis: Patient interview data will be evaluated using a constant comparative
      approach with a combination of inductively and deductively determined codes.

      Expected outcomes: The eConsult service has the potential to greatly reduce the number of
      unnecessary referrals, which will reduce overall wait times and provide specialists with
      more time to see patients with more urgent needs. By implementing this system, it is
      anticipated that there will be a reduction in avoidable referrals, decreased patient wait
      times and improved communication between primary and specialty care.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Any practicing primary care provider (PCP) in Ontario  who is not currently
             registered to use the Champlain BASE eConsult service may be recruited to participate
             in the research study, beginning with the Champlain and South East  Local Health
             Integration Networks.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Those not meeting the inclusion criteria.

intervention.description: Building on a recent successful pilot project, and using a pre-existing secure web-based collaboration space, primary care providers will submit a patient-specific clinical question to a specialist using a standardized electronic form that permits attachments (e.g., laboratory results, digital images). The specialist responds within one week by either: i) directly answering the question (negating the need for referral), ii) asking for additional patient information, or iii) requesting an in-person referral.

keyword: Reducing wait times for specialist care

facility.name: Bruyere Research Institute, C. T. Lamont Primary Health Care Research Centre

clinical_study.official_title: Building Capacity for Specialized Services Through eConsultation

overall_official.affiliation: Bruyere Research Institute, C. T. Lamont Primary Health Care Research Centre

oversight_info.authority: Canada: Ministry of Health & Long Term Care, Ontario

primary_outcome.description: We will compare the change in referral rates from the Institute of Clinical and Evaluative Sciences (ICES) using the Ontario Health Insurance Plan (OHIP) and ICES Physician database (IPDB) between baseline and intervention years for both Groups will controlling for temporal effects. This will include referrals and their costing algorithms.

reference.citation: Liddy C, Maranger J, Afkham A, Keely E. Ten steps to establishing an e-consultation service to improve access to specialist care. Telemed J E Health. 2013 Dec;19(12):982-90. doi: 10.1089/tmj.2013.0056. Epub 2013 Sep 27.

Keely E, Liddy C, Afkham A. Utilization, benefits, and impact of an e-consultation service across diverse specialties and primary care providers. Telemed J E Health. 2013 Oct;19(10):733-8. doi: 10.1089/tmj.2013.0007. Epub 2013 Aug 27.
Liddy C, Rowan MS, Afkham A, Maranger J, Keely E. Building access to specialist care through e-consultation. Open Med. 2013 Jan 8;7(1):e1-8. Print 2013.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Primary Care Pre-Randomization Practice Survey: This survey will be filled out by participating physicians who provide consent.  It will enable us to understand the characteristics of the physician practices, as well as their referral habits. This survey will be filled out during or prior to randomization as a baseline survey. We created this survey by adapting two validated Pan-Canadian Primary Health Care Provider & Practice Surveys from the Canadian Institutes for Health Information (CIHI). This survey will be filled out electronically or via fax/email.
Primary Care Provider questionnaire at the end of each eConsultation. This questionnaire is done electronically, as a pop-up screen following each eConsult

Post-Study Participant Satisfaction Survey: This survey will be done using an electronic survey method with options to complete via email, mail or fax. It  includes questions about the overall satisfaction with the Champlain BASE eConsult service.

These include; number of eConsults, number of participating physicians, type of advice requested, time required to respond to consultation, outcome of consultation (e.g. Further investigations, treatment initiated, consultation avoided), satisfaction with process, barriers and enablers, number of referrals from each participating physician.
secondary_outcome.measure: Number and types of eConsults & treatments; overall provider satifisaction

collaborator.agency: Ontario Ministry of Health and Long Term Care

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Health Services Research
